Furthermore, the case background states "no other typical injuries of a death due to smothering were found, such as petechiae," which implies a lack of obvious external signs of smothering.

Considering all these points, even if Jane is guilty, it is highly probable that the injuries found on Ben were either not physically present yet (like the dislocated ribs), or were internal and not externally discernible (spinal bleeding, hypoxic damage), or were subtle enough to be overlooked by nurses during initial assessment (eye/eyelid haemorrhages).
